title: Chapter 2: Effort
content:
Chapter 2:
Effort

EVEN WITH THE order coming from a major politician, things didn't progress easily.

The Human Resource Development Plan was still in its conceptual stage, and we had yet to secure funding; in other words, we were practically starting from a blank slate.

Except for the indispensable framework—'nurturing from infancy'—everything else could change dramatically.

We'd need to adapt flexibly to changing circumstances.

"…This project is going to be troublesome."

I sat at my desk cluttered with papers, my feet up, staring down at the documents.

One wrong move in how we approach this, and the project wouldn't only be criticized, but it would also draw severe disapproval.

We aren't exploiting children; we're creating facilities to save them.

That was the impression we had to give to the public.

But that's only if the project actually starts.

For now, in this preliminary phase, it was about gathering children to experiment on and securing a huge budget.

And we'd need a way to secure the children.

I dialed an eleven-digit number I had memorized.

"It's me. Put Ooba on. I have a new job for him."

First, I needed to think of an approach using whatever pieces I could, regardless of morality.

After Ooba answered the phone, I explained that I was looking for ways to acquire newborns and asked for his advice on what to do.

But contacting Ooba meant that using evil means was unavoidable.

During the conversation, a buzzer-like chime sounded.

"Sorry, I'll contact you again."

I ended the conversation with Ooba midway and decided to attend to the visitor.

"Good morning. It's Kamogawa. Are you there, Ayanokouji-san?"

"Come in. I didn't lock the door."

"If you'll excuse me…"

In a shabby office near the city center, costing about a hundred thousand yen in rent, Kamogawa showed a gloomy face.

"Uwahh."

As soon as he opened the door, Kamogawa showed a blatantly disrespectful attitude.

However, I didn't bother to point it out each time. It was a common reaction among visitors.

"Are you perhaps living in this office, Ayanokouji-san? It kind of smells like it's been lived in…"

The beer cans scattered at my feet, the unwashed sheets on the worn sofa, and the clothes carelessly thrown off would easily suggest as much even to a child.

"What about it?"

"No, it's not that there's a problem… It's just not like you…"

"Does it not match a Diet member's annual salary?"

A Diet member's monthly salary easily exceeded a million yen. With the proportionate bonuses, the total could exceed twenty million yen a year. Various allowances were also provided under different names.

"My colleague Kisarazu-san, who is three years older than me, boasted about how he signed a contract for the top floor of a tower mansion[1] in the city center just a week after becoming a member of Diet. Even a loan that normally wouldn't pass, he got approved in one shot."

"It's not because he's a Diet member."

"Eh?"

"Indeed, a Diet member's salary is high when you look at it from the perspective of your average company. However, whether it's the House of Representatives or the Senate, they're forced to face elections every few years. A bank wouldn't lend large amounts of money just based on the title to such an unstable job."

"But Kisarazu-san got it approved…"

"The loan amount, the bank involved, and the connections—there are plenty of conditions that can be arranged to get it approved."

"Oh, I see… I wouldn't get approved, huh…?"

It was the opposite. Indeed, Kamogawa himself might have a lower individual rating than Kisarazu, but the banks would see through to his father, Kamogawa Toshizou.

If they heard he was looking for a loan, bank employees from several banks would likely come to meet Kamogawa.

Of course, they'd even bring a box of sweets or two.

"How trivial."

"Trivial, you say? Doesn't everyone aspire to live in a luxury tower mansion?"

"Kamogawa. I'm telling you this for your own good, don't mimic the likes of Kisarazu."

If he were a member of Diet just for the money, it wouldn't be surprising to see him spend it on such trivial things.

"I'm not saying don't buy real estate. I'm just saying don't miss the right timing. Money is finite, but it holds infinite possibilities."

"I see…"

Kamogawa, despite not quite understanding, nodded as if he did.

"If you suddenly had a hundred million yen in front of you, what would you do?"

"Eh? A hundred million yen? I'd save about ninety million, and spend ten million on fun stuff, like going to hostess clubs or buying a car. Maybe I'd even invest a bit in stocks. If I had two hundred million, I'd buy a mansion."

In a way, it was a typical response. However, it was no different from Kisarazu in its triviality.

"You'd use it differently, right, Ayanokouji-san? What would you do?"

"Figure it out yourself."

"Eh~? Come on, tell me~"

If I suddenly had a hundred million yen, I'd probably spend it all within a few days.

As a means to connect with the financial world, there were various methods of investment for the future. This included acquisitions and bribes.

There was no time to spend money on an office or home when even a small change was precious.

The hundred million yen invested upfront should come back as a significantly larger return in a few years or decades.

And if that came along with the title of the nation's most powerful position—the final destination—then it was perfect.

"So, what are you here for?"

"How can you say that? I'm here to help you, Ayanokouji-san, just as Naoe-sensei instructed."

"I don't need it."

"That won't do. I'm one of the people who heard about that project. I don't mind if you take all the credit, but I…"

Kamogawa might live clumsily and awkwardly, but his desire for achievement was understandable. Indeed, it wasn't easy to find such opportunities. However, being a Diet member is fundamentally a job without the concept of days off. They were non-permanent tokubetsu shoku[2].

Moreover, it was currently the parliamentary session. Participating in policy study groups and research meetings within the Citizens' Party, attending to supporters and petitioners, and managing political and official duties filled most of the schedule.

"Can you be of use?"

"I'll show you I can be. After all, I'm still Kamogawa Toshizou's son, you know?"

That said, your father hasn't left much of a mark in the political world.

But I guess I can't just casually ignore Naoe-sensei's instructions.

"Then, as you wish, let's see you be of use. I'll give you a task."

Kamogawa's eyes sparkled, having never been given a significant role before.

"What kind of job is it?"

"For the project in question, it's essential to secure an experimental facility. I'll leave the location selection to you. Consider the scale, budget, and whether it can avoid public attention. If that goes well, you'll move on to the next task. You want to be a respectable Diet member recognized by Naoe-sensei, don't you?"

"Ah, I see. Indeed, that's something unavoidable."

"Even if it doesn't match the scale of ANHS, we need to increase the number of children annually. Naturally, you have to choose a suitable size. Moreover, maintaining anonymity is also crucial."

This project couldn't be promoted on a large scale.

We had to prevent journalists from reporting it as dangerous education for infants.

"From a budgetary perspective, seems like it'll inevitably be in the countryside."

Kamogawa's foolish expression changed.

He was a man who had been soaking in lukewarm water[3], but he didn't find joy in being called a second-generation politician. If given the right job and the right words of praise, he might be somewhat useful. No, he has to be.

"I understand. I'll try."

"That's good. You've finally made a decent face."

"Is that so?"

A little praise, and that decent face quickly retreated.

"What will you do now, Ayanokouji-san?"

"First and foremost, money is essential to planning the facility. I'll start preparing for that."

The conditions we envisioned would require a considerable cost at the initial stage.

Additionally, including personnel recruitment, I wanted to prepare about five hundred million.

If we wanted to be safe, we'd need over six hundred or seven hundred million…

"You mean you're going to talk about this project and get funding that way, right?"

"Of course, that's the aim."

"They'd be pleased to provide gifted education to children, wouldn't they?"

He really couldn't see the future.

Who would invest in a project that's still at its conceptual stage, when it's just a few pieces of paper?

Even if we were just talking about the wealthy, it wasn't an amount they would easily part with.

Of course, politicians couldn't officially receive direct donations, so they'd have to go through organizations like support groups.

There were limits to receiving donations, but finding a politician who strictly adhered to them was harder. There were countless ways to circumvent donation limits.

However, even on such a flimsy basis, with just a couple of words, if Naoe-sensei were to simply say, 'Do it,' a large sum of money would miraculously appear.

Since that wasn't an option, finding a major investor to start with was urgent business.

Even if my influence isn't on Naoe-sensei's level, I only have to be able to make an investor believe that he'll invest.

If I can achieve that, raising nearly five hundred million won't be impossible.

I sent Kamogawa off to work as if I were pushing him out of the office, and I took out three bankbooks from the desk. There were deposits from three different local banks.

"All together… it's just under ten million."

It wasn't a very dependable war chest, but it was all I had to start hitting targets with.

  1. [1]: A "tower mansion" is a Japanese term referring to tall condominiums that are at least twenty floors high.

  2. [2]: Tokubetsu shoku is a special position in the Japanese civil service that's exempted from application of the Local Public Service Act.

  3. [3]: "Soaking in lukewarm water" is a Japanese idiom that conveys that the individual "soaking" is staying in a comfortable and risk-free environment, suggesting that they don't need to work much.
